summary: This is a civil complaint filed in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida by Jane Doe No. 1, a minor, through her father and stepmother, against Jeffrey Epstein. The complaint alleges that in or about 2005, when Jane Doe was 14, Epstein sexually assaulted her at his Palm Beach mansion as part of a scheme involving the recruitment of underage girls. The plaintiffs seek damages in excess of $50 million for sexual assault, intentional infliction of emotional distress, and loss of parental consortium.

events.title: Alleged Sexual Assault of Jane Doe No. 1
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein allegedly sexually assaulted Jane Doe No. 1, then 14 years old, at his Palm Beach mansion as part of a described scheme to recruit underage girls for 'massages'.

events.title: Filing of Civil Complaint
events.description: Jane Doe No. 1, through her father and stepmother, files a civil lawsuit against Jeffrey Epstein in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida, seeking damages in excess of $50 million.

locations: Little St. James (private island in St. Thomas)
Miami, Florida (law firm address: 18205 Biscayne Blvd.)
keyFacts: The complaint alleges Jeffrey Epstein operated a scheme to sexually assault underage, economically disadvantaged girls, recruiting them for 'massages' at his Palm Beach mansion.
The specific plaintiff, Jane Doe No. 1, alleges she was assaulted by Epstein in or about 2005 when she was 14 years old, following the described pattern of recruitment and payment.

The complaint details Epstein's alleged modus operandi: using a recruiter to find girls, gathering their information, isolating them in a room with a massage table and nude photographs, and then assaulting them while naked.
The lawsuit seeks damages exceeding $50 million for sexual assault, intentional infliction of emotional distress (for Jane Doe and her parents), and loss of parental consortium.
The document identifies the law firm Herman & Mermelstein, P.A., and attorneys Jeffrey M. Herman, Stuart S. Mermelstein, and Adam D. Horowitz as representing the plaintiffs.
